results.definition: (usually plural) the status or rank or office of a Christian clergyman in an ecclesiastical hierarchy
assign a rank or rating to
a commercial document used to request someone to supply something in return for payment and providing specifications and quantities
examples: IBM received an order for a hundred computers

results.definition: a group of person living under a religious rule
hasTypes: order of our lady of mount carmel

results.definition: give instructions to or direct somebody to do something with authority
examples: She ordered him to do the shopping

results.definition: appoint to a clerical posts
issue commands or orders for
a degree in a continuum of size or quantity
examples: it was on the order of a mile
an explosion of a low order of magnitude

results.definition: a condition of regular or proper arrangement
examples: he put his desk in order
the machine is now in working order

results.definition: a body of rules followed by an assembly
a legally binding command or decision entered on the court record (as if issued by a court or judge)
examples: a friend in New Mexico said that the order caused no trouble out there

results.definition: arrange thoughts, ideas, temporal events
the act of putting things in a sequential arrangement
examples: there were mistakes in the ordering of items on the list

results.definition: a formal association of people with similar interests
examples: men from the fraternal order will staff the soup kitchen today

results.definition: logical or comprehensible arrangement of separate elements
examples: we shall consider these questions in the inverse order of their presentation

results.definition: bring into conformity with rules or principles or usage; impose regulations
(architecture) one of original three styles of Greek architecture distinguished by the type of column and entablature used or a style developed from the original three by the Romans
a request for something to be made, supplied, or served
examples: I gave the waiter my order
the company's products were in such demand that they got more orders than their call center could handle

bring order to or into
established customary state (especially of society)
make a request for something

examples: the British ships dropped anchor and waited for orders from London

results.definition: place in a certain order
